metadata.title: Prince Albert times and Saskatchewan review (1883-01-10)

snippets.text:
Thus imputing negligence on the part of the man whose lips are sealed by death. Subsequent enquiry has elicited the fact that there is a difference of opinion upon this point. Some say that he went to the side of the wheel where there was a sort of a platform, and that if he was on the wrong side, then the platform must also be on the wrong side; again, others say that he went up on the right side by which access could be had to the wheel.

Whatever story may be correct and at present we pass no opinion upon the subject, sufficient is known to show that there was abundant need for an investigation, whatever may have been the result. It is but fair to state, that the Chief Factor of the Hudson Bay Company, Hon. Lawrence Clarke, Esq., and Col. Richardson, who happened to be in town, immediately after the occurrence of his office as Superintendent, Macarthur holds the position of coroner in the North West Territories, and expressed his willingness to investigate the matter, if arrangements were made for it, as required.

We had the pleasure of a conversation with old Mr. George McKay the other day, and while talking about his age, he said that he had just about completed his 90th yearâ€”to-day or tomorrow. Mr. McKay undoubtedly the oldest settler on the Red River, having come to this country in 1823, when he was only 16 years of age, and been here ever since. His remains are the only history of this country are very interesting. He has lived through many changes, and his body, as we purpose spending an hour so with him tomorrow day in order to get a few facts regarding the early history of this country in its earlier days. We can imagine the old gentleman telling us of the adventures that took place, and how he will live to see more of them. On the morning of our visit to him, he was engaged in writing on a piece of paper, which he had placed on a table below, whilst his pipe was out, and his eyes and ears are fine and sharp.

SPINK & MAVETY, PROPRIETORS.
**Masonic Funeral**

Burial of Mr. Hiram Budd, late master of the Masonic Lodge at Coburg.

On Sunday last, the funeral of Mr. S. Graham, who died last week, took place at the Harmony Church, Wiseman street, and was attended by many friends and relatives.

The body was carried by members of the lodge and laid to rest in the family vault.

---

**Town News**

All changes for last, December, are hereby posted.

The far south passage will close at noon today.

Rev. Mr. Clark, of Bathurst, who has been spending his summer holidays in Prince Edward Island, has returned home yesterday.

The Rev. Mr. Macdonald, whilst here, visited with many friends, and expressed very strong opinions against the proposed amalgamation of the two parishes at St. Mary's Church.

Sergt. John Reid, left for Duck Lake, on the 21st inst., to meet Col. Henderson, who is stationed there.

Mr. Judge, of Bathurst, socio at the club hall, went to Winnipeg, with a proposition for some new members.

Dick Lahey, of St. John's, returned to Prince Edward Island, where he expects to remain until after the election.

---

**Best Baking Powder**

Dr.
